mn133:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā rājagahe viharati tapodārāme.
mn133:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha in the Hot Springs Monastery.
mn133:1.2.comm: The hot springs near Rājagaha were a popular place for monks to bathe, so much so that they prompted a rule ensuring that the monks did not monopolize the springs (Bu Pc 57). They are still in use and just as popular as ever.

mn133:1.3.pli: Atha kho āyasmā samiddhi rattiyā paccūsasamayaṃ paccuṭṭhāya yena tapodo tenupasaṅkami gattāni parisiñcituṃ.
mn133:1.3.eng: Then Venerable Samiddhi rose at the crack of dawn and went to the hot springs to bathe.
mn133:1.3.comm: Soon after he went forth, a deity in the same location tempted Samiddhi to enjoy sensual delights (SN 1.20). Had he succumbed, that would have been a case of “faltering amid presently arisen phenomena”. Samiddhi further appears in discourses at MN 136, where he had gone forth only three years, and AN 9.14 , where he seems more mature. In SN 4.22, Māra threatens to shake his faith, prompting him to ask the Buddha about Māra’s true nature (SN 35.65). This event is recalled in his verse at Thag 1.46.

mn133:1.4.pli: Tapode gattāni parisiñcitvā paccuttaritvā ekacīvaro aṭṭhāsi gattāni pubbāpayamāno.
mn133:1.4.eng: When he had bathed and emerged from the water he stood in one robe drying his limbs.

mn133:1.5.pli: Atha kho aññatarā devatā abhikkantāya rattiyā abhikkantavaṇṇā kevalakappaṃ tapodaṃ obhāsetvā yenāyasmā samiddhi tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā ekamantaṃ aṭṭhāsi. Ekamantaṃ ṭhitā kho sā devatā āyasmantaṃ samiddhiṃ etadavoca:
mn133:1.5.eng: Then, late at night, a glorious deity, lighting up the entire hot springs, went up to Samiddhi, stood to one side, and said to Samiddhi:

mn133:2.1.eng: “Mendicant, do you remember the summary recital and the analysis of the one who has one fine night?”

mn133:2.2.pli: “Na kho ahaṃ, āvuso, dhāremi bhaddekarattassa uddesañca vibhaṅgañca.

mn133:2.3.pli: Tvaṃ panāvuso, dhāresi bhaddekarattassa uddesañca vibhaṅgañcā”ti?

mn133:2.4.pli: “Ahampi kho, bhikkhu, na dhāremi bhaddekarattassa uddesañca vibhaṅgañca.

mn133:2.5.pli: Dhāresi pana tvaṃ, bhikkhu, bhaddekarattiyo gāthā”ti?
mn133:2.5.eng: But do you remember just the verses on the one who has one fine night?”
mn133:2.5.comm: The “verses” are, in fact, the same thing as the “recitation passage” mentioned above. The Tibetan and Chinese parallels lack the doubled question.

mn133:2.6.pli: “Na kho ahaṃ, āvuso, dhāremi bhaddekarattiyo gāthāti.

mn133:2.8.pli: “Ahampi kho, bhikkhu na dhāremi bhaddekarattiyo gāthāti.

mn133:2.9.pli: Uggaṇhāhi tvaṃ, bhikkhu, bhaddekarattassa uddesañca vibhaṅgañca;
mn133:2.9.eng: Learn the summary recital and the analysis of the one who has one fine night, mendicant,

mn133:2.10.pli: pariyāpuṇāhi tvaṃ, bhikkhu, bhaddekarattassa uddesañca vibhaṅgañca;

mn133:2.11.pli: dhārehi tvaṃ, bhikkhu, bhaddekarattassa uddesañca vibhaṅgañca.

mn133:2.12.pli: Atthasaṃhito, bhikkhu, bhaddekarattassa uddeso ca vibhaṅgo ca ādibrahmacariyako”ti.
mn133:2.12.eng: It is beneficial and relevant to the fundamentals of the spiritual life.”

mn133:3.1.pli: Atha kho āyasmā samiddhi tassā rattiyā accayena yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho āyasmā samiddhi bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
mn133:3.1.eng: Then, when the night had passed, Samiddhi went to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and told him what had happened. Then he added:

mn133:3.2.pli: “Idhāhaṃ, bhante, rattiyā paccūsasamayaṃ paccuṭṭhāya yena tapodo tenupasaṅkamiṃ gattāni parisiñcituṃ.

mn133:3.3.pli: Tapode gattāni parisiñcitvā paccuttaritvā ekacīvaro aṭṭhāsiṃ gattāni pubbāpayamāno.

mn133:3.4.pli: Atha kho bhante, aññatarā devatā abhikkantāya rattiyā abhikkantavaṇṇā kevalakappaṃ tapodaṃ obhāsetvā yenāhaṃ tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā ekamantaṃ aṭṭhāsi. Ekamantaṃ ṭhitā kho sā devatā maṃ etadavoca:

mn133:4.1.pli: Evaṃ vutte, ahaṃ, bhante, taṃ devataṃ etadavocaṃ:

mn133:4.2.pli: ‘na kho ahaṃ, āvuso, dhāremi bhaddekarattassa uddesañca vibhaṅgañca.

mn133:4.3.pli: Tvaṃ panāvuso, dhāresi bhaddekarattassa uddesañca vibhaṅgañcā’ti?

mn133:4.4.pli: ‘Ahampi kho, bhikkhu, na dhāremi bhaddekarattassa uddesañca vibhaṅgañca.

mn133:4.5.pli: Dhāresi pana tvaṃ, bhikkhu, bhaddekarattiyo gāthā’ti?

mn133:4.6.pli: ‘Na kho ahaṃ, āvuso, dhāremi bhaddekarattiyo gāthāti.

mn133:4.8.pli: ‘Ahampi kho, bhikkhu, na dhāremi bhaddekarattiyo gāthāti.

mn133:4.9.pli: Uggaṇhāhi tvaṃ, bhikkhu, bhaddekarattassa uddesañca vibhaṅgañca;

mn133:4.10.pli: pariyāpuṇāhi tvaṃ, bhikkhu, bhaddekarattassa uddesañca vibhaṅgañca;

mn133:4.11.pli: dhārehi tvaṃ, bhikkhu, bhaddekarattassa uddesañca vibhaṅgañca.

mn133:4.12.pli: Atthasaṃhito, bhikkhu, bhaddekarattassa uddeso ca vibhaṅgo ca ādibrahmacariyako’ti.

mn133:4.15.pli: Sādhu me, bhante, bhagavā bhaddekarattassa uddesañca vibhaṅgañca desetū”ti.
mn133:4.15.eng: “Sir, please teach me the summary recital and the analysis of the one who has one fine night.”

mn133:4.16.pli: “Tena hi, bhikkhu, suṇāhi, sādhukaṃ manasi karohi; bhāsissāmī”ti.
mn133:4.16.eng: “Well then, mendicant, listen and apply your mind well, I will speak.”

mn133:4.17.pli: “Evaṃ, bhante”ti kho āyasmā samiddhi bhagavato paccassosi.

mn133:5.6.eng: you clearly discern in every case.

mn133:5.9.eng: Today’s the day to keenly work—

mn133:5.10.eng: who knows, tomorrow may bring death!

mn133:5.11.eng: For there is no bargain to be struck

mn133:5.12.eng: with Death and his mighty horde.

mn133:5.13.eng: One who keenly meditates like this,

mn133:5.15.eng: that’s who has one fine night—

mn133:6.1.eng: That is what the Buddha said.

mn133:6.2.pli: idaṃ vatvāna sugato uṭṭhāyāsanā vihāraṃ pāvisi.
mn133:6.2.eng: When he had spoken, the Holy One got up from his seat and entered his dwelling.
mn133:6.2.comm: Though he set to teach the “recitation passage and analysis”, the Buddha omits the analysis, so the monks ask Mahākaccāna for the analysis. The same situation obtains in MN 138:4.2. In both cases the Chinese and Tibetan parallels avoid the problem, since the Buddha only says he will teach the verses. Contrast the situation at MN 137:2.1 and MN 139:2.1.

mn133:7.1.pli: Atha kho tesaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ, acirapakkantassa bhagavato, etadahosi:
mn133:7.1.eng: Soon after the Buddha left, those mendicants considered,

mn133:7.2.pli: “idaṃ kho no, āvuso, bhagavā saṅkhittena uddesaṃ uddisitvā vitthārena atthaṃ avibhajitvā uṭṭhāyāsanā vihāraṃ paviṭṭho:
mn133:7.2.eng: “The Buddha gave this brief summary recital, then entered his dwelling without explaining the meaning in detail. …

mn133:7.19.pli: Ko nu kho imassa bhagavatā saṅkhittena uddesassa uddiṭṭhassa vitthārena atthaṃ avibhattassa vitthārena atthaṃ vibhajeyyā”ti?
mn133:7.19.eng: Who can explain in detail the meaning of this brief summary given by the Buddha?”

mn133:7.21.pli: “ayaṃ kho āyasmā mahākaccāno satthu ceva saṃvaṇṇito sambhāvito ca viññūnaṃ sabrahmacārīnaṃ;
mn133:7.21.eng: “This Venerable Mahākaccāna is praised by the Buddha and esteemed by his sensible spiritual companions.

mn133:7.22.pli: pahoti cāyasmā mahākaccāno imassa bhagavatā saṅkhittena uddesassa uddiṭṭhassa vitthārena atthaṃ avibhattassa vitthārena atthaṃ vibhajituṃ.
mn133:7.22.eng: He is capable of explaining in detail the meaning of this brief summary recital given by the Buddha.

mn133:7.23.pli: Yannūna mayaṃ yenāyasmā mahākaccāno tenupasaṅkameyyāma; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmantaṃ mahākaccānaṃ etamatthaṃ paṭipuccheyyāmā”ti.
mn133:7.23.eng: Let’s go to him, and ask him about this matter.”

mn133:7.24.pli: Atha kho te bhikkhū yenāyasmā mahākaccāno tenupasaṅkamiṃsu; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmatā mahākaccānena saddhiṃ sammodiṃsu.
mn133:7.24.eng: Then those mendicants went to Mahākaccāna, and exchanged greetings with him.

mn133:7.25.pli: Sammodanīyaṃ kathaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ vītisāretvā ekamantaṃ nisīdiṃsu. Ekamantaṃ nisinnā kho te bhikkhū āyasmantaṃ mahākaccānaṃ etadavocuṃ:
mn133:7.25.eng: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, they sat down to one side. They told him what had happened, and said:

mn133:7.26.pli: “idaṃ kho no, āvuso kaccāna, bhagavā saṅkhittena uddesaṃ uddisitvā vitthārena atthaṃ avibhajitvā uṭṭhāyāsanā vihāraṃ paviṭṭho:

mn133:7.31.pli: Tesaṃ no, āvuso kaccāna, amhākaṃ, acirapakkantassa bhagavato, etadahosi—

mn133:7.32.pli: idaṃ kho no, āvuso, bhagavā saṅkhittena uddesaṃ uddisitvā vitthārena atthaṃ avibhajitvā uṭṭhāyāsanā vihāraṃ paviṭṭho:

mn133:8.1.pli: Ko nu kho imassa bhagavatā saṅkhittena uddesassa uddiṭṭhassa vitthārena atthaṃ avibhattassa vitthārena atthaṃ vibhajeyyāti?

mn133:8.2.pli: Tesaṃ no, āvuso kaccāna, amhākaṃ etadahosi:

mn133:8.3.pli: ‘ayaṃ kho āyasmā mahākaccāno satthu ceva saṃvaṇṇito sambhāvito ca viññūnaṃ sabrahmacārīnaṃ.

mn133:8.4.pli: Pahoti cāyasmā mahākaccāno imassa bhagavatā saṅkhittena uddesassa uddiṭṭhassa vitthārena atthaṃ avibhattassa vitthārena atthaṃ vibhajituṃ.

mn133:8.5.pli: Yannūna mayaṃ yenāyasmā mahākaccāno tenupasaṅkameyyāma; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmantaṃ mahākaccānaṃ etamatthaṃ paṭipuccheyyāmā’ti.

mn133:9.1.pli: “Seyyathāpi, āvuso, puriso sāratthiko sāragavesī sārapariyesanaṃ caramāno mahato rukkhassa tiṭṭhato sāravato atikkammeva mūlaṃ atikkamma khandhaṃ sākhāpalāse sāraṃ pariyesitabbaṃ maññeyya;
mn133:9.1.eng: “Reverends, suppose there was a person in need of heartwood. And while wandering in search of heartwood he’d come across a large tree standing with heartwood. But he’d pass over the roots and trunk, imagining that the heartwood should be sought in the branches and leaves.

mn133:9.2.pli: evaṃsampadamidaṃ āyasmantānaṃ satthari sammukhībhūte taṃ bhagavantaṃ atisitvā amhe etamatthaṃ paṭipucchitabbaṃ maññatha.
mn133:9.2.eng: Such is the consequence for the venerables. Though you were face to face with the Buddha, you bypassed him, imagining that you should ask me about this matter.

mn133:9.3.pli: So hāvuso, bhagavā jānaṃ jānāti, passaṃ passati, cakkhubhūto ñāṇabhūto dhammabhūto brahmabhūto vattā pavattā atthassa ninnetā amatassa dātā dhammassāmī tathāgato.
mn133:9.3.eng: For he is the Buddha, the one who knows and sees. He is vision, he is knowledge, he is the manifestation of principle, he is the manifestation of divinity. He is the teacher, the proclaimer, the elucidator of meaning, the bestower of freedom from death, the lord of truth, the Realized One.

mn133:9.4.pli: So ceva panetassa kālo ahosi yaṃ bhagavantaṃyeva etamatthaṃ paṭipuccheyyātha, yathā vo bhagavā byākareyya tathā naṃ dhāreyyāthā”ti.
mn133:9.4.eng: That was the time to approach the Buddha and ask about this matter. You should have remembered it in line with the Buddha’s answer.”

mn133:10.1.pli: “Addhāvuso kaccāna, bhagavā jānaṃ jānāti, passaṃ passati, cakkhubhūto ñāṇabhūto dhammabhūto brahmabhūto vattā pavattā atthassa ninnetā amatassa dātā dhammassāmī tathāgato.
mn133:10.1.eng: “Certainly he is the Buddha, the one who knows and sees. He is vision, he is knowledge, he is the manifestation of principle, he is the manifestation of divinity. He is the teacher, the proclaimer, the elucidator of meaning, the bestower of freedom from death, the lord of truth, the Realized One.

mn133:10.2.pli: So ceva panetassa kālo ahosi yaṃ bhagavantaṃyeva etamatthaṃ paṭipuccheyyāma;
mn133:10.2.eng: That was the time to approach the Buddha and ask about this matter.

mn133:10.3.pli: yathā no bhagavā byākareyya tathā naṃ dhāreyyāma.
mn133:10.3.eng: We should have remembered it in line with the Buddha’s answer.

mn133:10.4.pli: Api cāyasmā mahākaccāno satthu ceva saṃvaṇṇito sambhāvito ca viññūnaṃ sabrahmacārīnaṃ;
mn133:10.4.eng: Still, Venerable Mahākaccāna is praised by the Buddha and esteemed by his sensible spiritual companions.

mn133:10.5.pli: pahoti cāyasmā mahākaccāno imassa bhagavatā saṅkhittena uddesassa uddiṭṭhassa vitthārena atthaṃ avibhattassa vitthārena atthaṃ vibhajituṃ.
mn133:10.5.eng: He is capable of explaining in detail the meaning of this brief summary recital given by the Buddha.

mn133:10.6.eng: Please explain this, if it’s no trouble.”

mn133:11.1.pli: “Tena hāvuso, suṇātha, sādhukaṃ manasi karotha, bhāsissāmī”ti.
mn133:11.1.eng: “Well then, reverends, listen and apply your mind well, I will speak.”

mn133:11.2.pli: “Evamāvuso”ti kho te bhikkhū āyasmato mahākaccānassa paccassosuṃ.

mn133:12.1.pli: “Yaṃ kho no, āvuso, bhagavā saṅkhittena uddesaṃ uddisitvā vitthārena atthaṃ avibhajitvā uṭṭhāyāsanā vihāraṃ paviṭṭho:
mn133:12.1.eng: “Reverends, the Buddha gave this brief summary recital, then entered his dwelling without explaining the meaning in detail:

mn133:12.4.eng: that’s who has one fine night—

mn133:12.6.pli: Imassa kho ahaṃ, āvuso, bhagavatā saṅkhittena uddesassa uddiṭṭhassa vitthārena atthaṃ avibhattassa evaṃ vitthārena atthaṃ ājānāmi—
mn133:12.6.eng: And this is how I understand the detailed meaning of this summary recital.

mn133:13.1.eng: And how do you run back to the past?

mn133:13.2.pli: Iti me cakkhu ahosi atītamaddhānaṃ iti rūpāti—
mn133:13.2.eng: Consciousness gets tied up there with desire and lust, thinking: ‘In the past I had such eyes and such sights.’
mn133:13.2.comm: As in MN 18:16.1 and MN 138:10.2, Kaccāna’s favored mode of analysis is through the six senses.

mn133:13.3.pli: tattha chandarāgappaṭibaddhaṃ hoti viññāṇaṃ, chandarāgappaṭibaddhattā viññāṇassa tadabhinandati, tadabhinandanto atītaṃ anvāgameti.
mn133:13.3.eng: So you take pleasure in that, and that’s when you run back to the past.

mn133:13.4.pli: Iti me sotaṃ ahosi atītamaddhānaṃ iti saddāti …pe…
mn133:13.4.eng: Consciousness gets tied up there with desire and lust, thinking: ‘In the past I had such ears and such sounds …

mn133:13.5.pli: iti me ghānaṃ ahosi atītamaddhānaṃ iti gandhāti …
mn133:13.5.eng: such a nose and such smells …

mn133:13.6.pli: iti me jivhā ahosi atītamaddhānaṃ iti rasāti …
mn133:13.6.eng: such a tongue and such tastes …

mn133:13.7.pli: iti me kāyo ahosi atītamaddhānaṃ iti phoṭṭhabbāti …
mn133:13.7.eng: such a body and such touches …

mn133:13.8.pli: iti me mano ahosi atītamaddhānaṃ iti dhammāti—
mn133:13.8.eng: such a mind and such ideas.’

mn133:13.9.pli: tattha chandarāgappaṭibaddhaṃ hoti viññāṇaṃ, chandarāgappaṭibaddhattā viññāṇassa tadabhinandati, tadabhinandanto atītaṃ anvāgameti—
mn133:13.9.eng: So you take pleasure in that, and that’s when you run back to the past.

mn133:13.10.eng: That’s how you run back to the past.

mn133:14.1.eng: And how do you not run back to the past?

mn133:14.2.pli: Iti me cakkhu ahosi atītamaddhānaṃ iti rūpāti—
mn133:14.2.eng: Consciousness doesn’t get tied up there with desire and lust, thinking: ‘In the past I had such eyes and such sights.’

mn133:14.3.pli: tattha na chandarāgappaṭibaddhaṃ hoti viññāṇaṃ, na chandarāgappaṭibaddhattā viññāṇassa na tadabhinandati, na tadabhinandanto atītaṃ nānvāgameti.
mn133:14.3.eng: So you don’t take pleasure in that, and that’s when you no longer run back to the past.

mn133:14.4.pli: Iti me sotaṃ ahosi atītamaddhānaṃ iti saddāti …pe…
mn133:14.4.eng: Consciousness doesn’t get tied up there with desire and lust, thinking: ‘In the past I had such ears and such sounds …

mn133:14.5.pli: iti me ghānaṃ ahosi atītamaddhānaṃ iti gandhāti …
mn133:14.5.eng: such a nose and such smells …

mn133:14.6.pli: iti me jivhā ahosi atītamaddhānaṃ iti rasāti …
mn133:14.6.eng: such a tongue and such tastes …

mn133:14.7.pli: iti me kāyo ahosi atītamaddhānaṃ iti phoṭṭhabbāti …
mn133:14.7.eng: such a body and such touches …

mn133:14.8.pli: iti me mano ahosi atītamaddhānaṃ iti dhammāti—
mn133:14.8.eng: such a mind and such ideas.’

mn133:14.9.pli: tattha na chandarāgappaṭibaddhaṃ hoti viññāṇaṃ, na chandarāgappaṭibaddhattā viññāṇassa, na tadabhinandati, na tadabhinandanto atītaṃ nānvāgameti—
mn133:14.9.eng: So you don’t take pleasure in that, and that’s when you no longer run back to the past.

mn133:14.10.eng: That’s how you don’t run back to the past.

mn133:15.1.eng: And how do you anticipate the future?

mn133:15.2.pli: Iti me cakkhu siyā anāgatamaddhānaṃ iti rūpāti—
mn133:15.2.eng: The heart is set on getting what it does not have, thinking: ‘May I have such eyes and such sights in the future.’

mn133:15.3.pli: appaṭiladdhassa paṭilābhāya cittaṃ paṇidahati, cetaso paṇidhānapaccayā tadabhinandati, tadabhinandanto anāgataṃ paṭikaṅkhati.
mn133:15.3.eng: So you take pleasure in that, and that’s when you anticipate the future.

mn133:15.4.pli: Iti me sotaṃ siyā anāgatamaddhānaṃ iti saddāti …pe…
mn133:15.4.eng: The heart is set on getting what it does not have, thinking: ‘May I have such ears and such sounds …

mn133:15.5.pli: iti me ghānaṃ siyā anāgatamaddhānaṃ iti gandhāti …
mn133:15.5.eng: such a nose and such smells …

mn133:15.6.pli: iti me jivhā siyā anāgatamaddhānaṃ iti rasāti …
mn133:15.6.eng: such a tongue and such tastes …

mn133:15.7.pli: iti me kāyo siyā anāgatamaddhānaṃ iti phoṭṭhabbāti …
mn133:15.7.eng: such a body and such touches …

mn133:15.8.pli: iti me mano siyā anāgatamaddhānaṃ iti dhammāti—
mn133:15.8.eng: such a mind and such ideas in the future.’

mn133:15.9.pli: appaṭiladdhassa paṭilābhāya cittaṃ paṇidahati, cetaso paṇidhānapaccayā tadabhinandati, tadabhinandanto anāgataṃ paṭikaṅkhati—
mn133:15.9.eng: So you take pleasure in that, and that’s when you anticipate the future.

mn133:15.10.eng: That’s how you anticipate the future.

mn133:16.1.eng: And how do you not anticipate the future?

mn133:16.2.pli: Iti me cakkhu siyā anāgatamaddhānaṃ iti rūpāti—
mn133:16.2.eng: The heart is not set on getting what it does not have, thinking: ‘May I have such eyes and such sights in the future.’

mn133:16.3.pli: appaṭiladdhassa paṭilābhāya cittaṃ nappaṇidahati, cetaso appaṇidhānapaccayā na tadabhinandati, na tadabhinandanto anāgataṃ nappaṭikaṅkhati.
mn133:16.3.eng: So you don’t take pleasure in that, and that’s when you no longer anticipate the future.

mn133:16.4.pli: Iti me sotaṃ siyā anāgatamaddhānaṃ iti saddāti …pe…
mn133:16.4.eng: The heart is not set on getting what it does not have, thinking: ‘May I have such ears and such sounds …

mn133:16.5.pli: iti me ghānaṃ siyā anāgatamaddhānaṃ iti gandhāti …
mn133:16.5.eng: such a nose and such smells …

mn133:16.6.pli: iti me jivhā siyā anāgatamaddhānaṃ iti rasāti …
mn133:16.6.eng: such a tongue and such tastes …

mn133:16.7.pli: iti me kāyo siyā anāgatamaddhānaṃ iti phoṭṭhabbāti …
mn133:16.7.eng: such a body and such touches …

mn133:16.8.pli: iti me mano siyā anāgatamaddhānaṃ iti dhammāti—
mn133:16.8.eng: such a mind and such ideas in the future.’

mn133:16.9.pli: appaṭiladdhassa paṭilābhāya cittaṃ nappaṇidahati, cetaso appaṇidhānapaccayā na tadabhinandati, na tadabhinandanto anāgataṃ nappaṭikaṅkhati—
mn133:16.9.eng: So you don’t take pleasure in that, and that’s when you no longer anticipate the future.

mn133:16.10.eng: That’s how you don’t anticipate the future.

mn133:17.1.eng: And how do you falter amid presently arisen phenomena?

mn133:17.4.pli: Tasmiñce paccuppanne chandarāgappaṭibaddhaṃ hoti viññāṇaṃ, chandarāgappaṭibaddhattā viññāṇassa tadabhinandati, tadabhinandanto paccuppannesu dhammesu saṃhīrati.
mn133:17.4.eng: If consciousness gets tied up there in the present with desire and lust, you take pleasure in that, and that’s when you falter amid presently arisen phenomena.

mn133:17.7.pli: yā cāvuso, jivhā ye ca rasā …

mn133:17.8.pli: yo cāvuso, kāyo ye ca phoṭṭhabbā …

mn133:17.9.pli: yo cāvuso, mano ye ca dhammā—
mn133:17.9.comm: Dhamma is rendered here with “ideas”, namely those things which are known by the mind. Where it is rendered “phenomena”, it includes the “ideas” as well as all else that is known.

mn133:17.11.pli: Tasmiñce paccuppanne chandarāgappaṭibaddhaṃ hoti viññāṇaṃ, chandarāgappaṭibaddhattā viññāṇassa tadabhinandati, tadabhinandanto paccuppannesu dhammesu saṃhīrati—
mn133:17.11.eng: If consciousness gets tied up there in the present with desire and lust, you take pleasure in that, and that’s when you falter amid presently arisen phenomena.

mn133:17.12.pli: evaṃ kho, āvuso, paccuppannesu dhammesu saṃhīrati.
mn133:17.12.eng: That’s how you falter amid presently arisen phenomena.

mn133:18.1.pli: Kathañca, āvuso, paccuppannesu dhammesu na saṃhīrati?
mn133:18.1.eng: And how do you not falter amid presently arisen phenomena?

mn133:18.4.pli: Tasmiñce paccuppanne na chandarāgappaṭibaddhaṃ hoti viññāṇaṃ, na chandarāgappaṭibaddhattā viññāṇassa na tadabhinandati, na tadabhinandanto paccuppannesu dhammesu na saṃhīrati.
mn133:18.4.eng: If consciousness doesn’t get tied up there in the present with desire and lust, you don’t take pleasure in that, and that’s when you no longer falter amid presently arisen phenomena.

mn133:18.7.pli: yā cāvuso, jivhā ye ca rasā …

mn133:18.8.pli: yo cāvuso, kāyo ye ca phoṭṭhabbā …

mn133:18.9.pli: yo cāvuso, mano ye ca dhammā—

mn133:18.11.pli: Tasmiñce paccuppanne na chandarāgappaṭibaddhaṃ hoti viññāṇaṃ, na chandarāgappaṭibaddhattā viññāṇassa na tadabhinandati, na tadabhinandanto paccuppannesu dhammesu na saṃhīrati—
mn133:18.11.eng: If consciousness doesn’t get tied up there in the present with desire and lust, you don’t take pleasure in that, and that’s when you no longer falter amid presently arisen phenomena.

mn133:18.12.pli: evaṃ kho, āvuso, paccuppannesu dhammesu na saṃhīrati.
mn133:18.12.eng: That’s how you don’t falter amid presently arisen phenomena.

mn133:19.1.pli: Yaṃ kho no, āvuso, bhagavā saṅkhittena uddesaṃ uddisitvā vitthārena atthaṃ avibhajitvā uṭṭhāyāsanā vihāraṃ paviṭṭho:
mn133:19.1.eng: This is how I understand the detailed meaning of that brief summary recital given by the Buddha.

mn133:19.6.pli: Imassa kho ahaṃ, āvuso, bhagavatā saṅkhittena uddesassa uddiṭṭhassa vitthārena atthaṃ avibhattassa evaṃ vitthārena atthaṃ ājānāmi.

mn133:19.7.pli: Ākaṅkhamānā ca pana tumhe āyasmanto bhagavantaṃyeva upasaṅkamitvā etamatthaṃ paṭipuccheyyātha,
mn133:19.7.eng: If you wish, you may go to the Buddha and ask him about this.

mn133:19.8.pli: yathā vo bhagavā byākaroti tathā naṃ dhāreyyāthā”ti.
mn133:19.8.eng: You should remember it in line with the Buddha’s answer.”

mn133:20.1.pli: Atha kho te bhikkhū āyasmato mahākaccānassa bhāsitaṃ abhinanditvā anumoditvā uṭṭhāyāsanā yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkamiṃsu; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdiṃsu. Ekamantaṃ nisinnā kho te bhikkhū bhagavantaṃ etadavocuṃ:
mn133:20.1.eng: Then those mendicants, approving and agreeing with what Mahākaccāna said, rose from their seats and went to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and told him what had happened, adding:

mn133:20.2.pli: “yaṃ kho no, bhante, bhagavā saṅkhittena uddesaṃ uddisitvā vitthārena atthaṃ avibhajitvā uṭṭhāyāsanā vihāraṃ paviṭṭho:

mn133:20.7.pli: Tesaṃ no, bhante, amhākaṃ, acirapakkantassa bhagavato, etadahosi:

mn133:20.8.pli: ‘idaṃ kho no, āvuso, bhagavā saṅkhittena uddesaṃ uddisitvā vitthārena atthaṃ avibhajitvā uṭṭhāyāsanā vihāraṃ paviṭṭho:

mn133:20.25.pli: Ko nu kho imassa bhagavatā saṅkhittena uddesassa uddiṭṭhassa vitthārena atthaṃ avibhattassa vitthārena atthaṃ vibhajeyyā’ti?

mn133:20.27.pli: ‘ayaṃ kho āyasmā mahākaccāno satthu ceva saṃvaṇṇito sambhāvito ca viññūnaṃ sabrahmacārīnaṃ.

mn133:20.28.pli: Pahoti cāyasmā mahākaccāno imassa bhagavatā saṅkhittena uddesassa uddiṭṭhassa vitthārena atthaṃ avibhattassa vitthārena atthaṃ vibhajituṃ.

mn133:20.29.pli: Yannūna mayaṃ yenāyasmā mahākaccāno tenupasaṅkameyyāma; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmantaṃ mahākaccānaṃ etamatthaṃ paṭipuccheyyāmā’ti.

mn133:20.30.pli: Atha kho mayaṃ, bhante, yenāyasmā mahākaccāno tenupasaṅkamimha; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmantaṃ mahākaccānaṃ etamatthaṃ paṭipucchimha.

mn133:20.31.pli: Tesaṃ no, bhante, āyasmatā mahākaccānena imehi ākārehi imehi padehi imehi byañjanehi attho vibhatto”ti.
mn133:20.31.eng: “Mahākaccāna clearly explained the meaning to us in this manner, with these words and phrases.”

mn133:21.1.eng: “Mahākaccāna is astute, mendicants, he has great wisdom.

mn133:21.2.pli: Mañcepi tumhe, bhikkhave, etamatthaṃ paṭipuccheyyātha, ahampi taṃ evamevaṃ byākareyyaṃ yathā taṃ mahākaccānena byākataṃ.
mn133:21.2.eng: If you came to me and asked this question, I would answer it in exactly the same way as Mahākaccāna.

mn133:21.3.pli: Eso cevetassa attho. Evañca naṃ dhārethā”ti.
mn133:21.3.eng: That is what it means, and that’s how you should remember it.”

mn133:21.4.eng: That is what the Buddha said.

mn133:21.5.pli: Attamanā te bhikkhū bhagavato bhāsitaṃ abhinandunti.
mn133:21.5.eng: Satisfied, the mendicants approved what the Buddha said.
